newsitem.title: USA: Novartis buys Merck unit for $910 mln.
newsitem.headline: Novartis buys Merck unit for $910 mln.

text.p: Novartis AG said Tuesday it had bought Merck & Co Inc's crop protection business for $910 million.
The company said the deal included the worldwide rights to the unit's business, which had 1996 sales of $200 million.
"(It had) a strong position in the high-value acaricide/insecticide and post-harvest fungicide markets," it said, referring to the products that protect crops against mites, insects and fungi.
Novartis, which specializes in chemicals and pharmaceuticals, said the deal also included about $21 million in product inventories.
It said it expected to close the deal "this summer."
Merck said in a separate statement that the sale of the unit was part of its strategy to focus on its core human and animal health businesses.
"Merck and Rhone-Poulenc will combine their animal health and poultry genetics businesses to form a new company, called Merial," it said.
A spokesman for Merck said Novartis made what the company considered was the best offer despite a number of other "financially aggressive" bidders.
Novartis said crop protection activities have been "very consistently profitable" with sales growing at a compounded annual growth rate of 12 percent during the last four years.
"Gross profit and operating income have grown at a compounded annual growth rate of 12 and 13 percent, respectively," it said.
The closing of the deal is subject to government approvals and other customary closing conditions.
